MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters. This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn. Provide your answer with these fields. - is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false), - scenario: a specific violation scenario. Here is the code of list_directory: ```c static enum MHD_Result list_directory (struct ResponseDataContext *rdc, const char *dirname) { char fullname[PATH_MAX]; struct stat sbuf; DIR *dir; struct dirent *de; if (NULL == (dir = opendir (dirname))) return MHD_NO; while (NULL != (de = readdir (dir))) { int res; if ('.' == de->d_name[0]) continue; if (sizeof (fullname) <= (unsigned int) snprintf (fullname, sizeof (fullname), "%s/%s", dirname, de->d_name)) continue; /* ugh, file too long? how can this be!? */ if (0 != stat (fullname, &sbuf)) continue; /* ugh, failed to 'stat' */ if (! S_ISREG (sbuf.st_mode)) continue; /* not a regular file, skip */ if (rdc->off + 1024 > rdc->buf_len) { void *r; if ( (2 * rdc->buf_len + 1024) < rdc->buf_len) break; /* more than SIZE_T _index_ size? Too big for us */ rdc->buf_len = 2 * rdc->buf_len + 1024; if (NULL == (r = realloc (rdc->buf, rdc->buf_len))) break; /* out of memory */ rdc->buf = r; } res = snprintf (&rdc->buf[rdc->off], rdc->buf_len - rdc->off, "
  • %s
    • \n", fullname, de->d_name); if (0 >= res) continue; /* snprintf() error */ if (rdc->buf_len - rdc->off <= (size_t) res) continue; /* buffer too small?? */ rdc->off += (size_t) res; } (void) closedir (dir); return MHD_YES; } ```     Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c if (rdc->buf_len - rdc->off <= (size_t) res) continue; /* buffer too small?? */ ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
scenario: No violation: the code checks snprintf()'s return value (res > 0 is enforced earlier) and then compares the number of characters snprintf would have written to the remaining buffer space via if (rdc->buf_len - rdc->off <= (size_t) res) continue;. Because snprintf() returns the number of characters that would have been written (excluding the terminating NUL), the test res >= remaining correctly detects truncation and prevents out‑of‑bounds writes. Negative res is handled earlier, and remaining is computed from size_t fields, so this fragment does not cause a string.h related out‑of‑bounds access (Rule 21.17). A violation scenario would occur if the code omitted the res <= 0 check before casting or computed the remaining size incorrectly (underflow), which could allow a truncated write to go unchecked.
